title: Survey of Open-Source Lightcurve Inversion Tools

tools.name: convexinv / conjgradinv
tools.capabilities: Convex shape inversion from dense lightcurves using spherical harmonics (convexinv) or direct facet areas (conjgradinv). Also includes lcgenerator for synthetic lightcurve computation.
tools.limitations: Convex shapes only. C code requires compilation. No sparse data handling. No GUI.

tools.name: ADAM (All-Data Asteroid Modeling)
tools.capabilities: Multi-modal reconstruction from lightcurves, AO images, radar delay-Doppler, interferometry, occultation timings. Non-convex and non-starlike shapes. Parallel execution support.
tools.limitations: Requires MATLAB license. Complex configuration. Needs initial shape from convex inversion.

tools.name: MPO LCInvert
tools.capabilities: GUI-based convex inversion wizard. Based on Kaasalainen-Durech algorithms. Step-by-step process from lightcurves to 3D model.
tools.limitations: Commercial product (not free). Windows only. Convex shapes only. No sparse data. No programmatic API.

tools.name: SAGE (Shaping Asteroids with Genetic Evolution)
tools.capabilities: Non-convex shape reconstruction via genetic algorithm. Tested on Eros, Metis. Can model craters, lobes, contact binaries.
tools.limitations: Source code not publicly released. Must be reimplemented from paper description.

tools.name: asteroid-inversion (MCMC)
tools.capabilities: Lightcurve simulation and shape recovery using MCMC. Educational/research implementation.
tools.limitations: MATLAB required. Less mature than convexinv. Limited documentation.

tools.name: Asteroids@home
tools.capabilities: Distributed computing for lightcurve inversion using BOINC framework. Massive parallelization across volunteer computers.
tools.limitations: Distributed infrastructure required. Not suitable for individual use.

summary: Six tools/repositories catalogued. The most relevant open-source tool is convexinv (DAMIT), which provides the foundation for convex inversion in C. SAGE is not publicly available and must be reimplemented. ADAM provides the most complete multi-modal framework but requires MATLAB. Our pipeline will reimplement the core algorithms in Python, synthesizing convex inversion (convexinv approach), genetic non-convex optimization (SAGE approach), and sparse data handling (Durech/Cellino approach) into a unified framework.
